artist: Artist: Francisco José de Goya y Lucientes
creditline: The Winton Jones Endowment Fund for Prints and Drawings
description: two men flanking a bull, each stabbing it with staffs, in the shoulder and PR side, in a spare grey landscape with trees at center middle ground
medium: Etching, burnished aquatint, drypoint, and burin
portfolio: From Plate 2 from the series La Tauromaquia (Madrid, 1816)
provenance: Tajan, Paris, May 21, 2015, nos. 42 and 46, for $2,955 and $3,939 respectively. A series of Tauromaquia plates came up at this sale in Paris this spring, where they were greatly underestimated.
text: In the 33-print series "Tauromaquia," Goya traces the history of bullfighting in Spain, from men hunting in open fields, as seen in Otro modo de cazar á pie (Another Way of Hunting on Foot), to the modern, ritualized spectacle it became in the 18th century. Goya captures the brut nature of the bull, whose mournful expression shows defeat as he struggles submissively to lift his head. The print is technically sophisticated in its combination of etching, drypoint, engraving, and the new medium of aquatint, which Goya deployed to luminous, evocative effect.
title: Otro modo de cazar á pie (Another Way of Hunting on Foot)
